Award.AwardTitle: Summer Social Webshop 2012: Technology-Mediated Social Participation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is funding to support a workshop for 40 promising graduate students from the United States whose research covers aspects of Technology-Mediated Social Participation (TMSP). Technology-mediated social participation is generated when social networking tools, blogs and microblogs, user-generated content sites, discussion groups, problem reporting, recommendation systems, and other social media are applied to national priorities such as health, energy, education, disaster response, environmental protection, business innovation, or community safety. Although social media are transforming society, many universities have been slow to integrate these novel technologies and social structures into their curricula and research. Two previous NSF-supported TMSP Workshops have outlined an agenda for research and education in this area, which was published in a serious of journal articles appearing in a special issue of IEEE Computer. To increase research and education in TMSP, this workshop brings together an interdisciplinary group of graduate students to listen to presentations by leaders in the field, learn new research skills, and learn from each other by sharing the diverse research streams that focus on social media.

The TMSP "webshop" will include 40 graduate students from such fields as sociology, anthropology, communications, psychology, journalism and humanities as well as from information studies, information systems, human-computer interaction and computer science. Effort will be taken to ensure gender balance, strong representation from ethnic minority groups, and cross-disciplinarity. Students will apply by submitting a one-page statement of why they wish to attend the workshop along with their curriculum vitae. During the three-day workshop, students will attend presentations from an interdisciplinary group of distinguished leaders in the field and engage in other research and community-building activities.

Intellectual Merit: There is a growing recognition that social media technologies can bring profound benefits for national priorities such as disaster response, community safety, health/wellness, energy sustainability, and environmental protection. However substantial research is needed to scale up participation, raise motivation, control malicious attacks, limit misguided rumors, and protect privacy. The TMSP workshop will foster new ideas, tools and theories in this area through intense multidisciplinary discussion. Topics to be covered share (1) a close linkage to compelling national priorities; (2) a scientific foundation based on established theories and well-defined research questions (privacy, reciprocity, trust, motivation, recognition, etc.); and (3) computer science research challenges (security, privacy protection, scalability, visualization, end-user development, distributed data handling, network analysis of community evolution, cross network comparison, etc.).

Broader impacts: The workshop will raise awareness of the importance of technology-mediated social participation as a distinct area of study, foster new interdisciplinary projects, raise the prominence of researchers and educators who are invited to speak, and promote greater understanding of the discipline among leading graduate students across the United States. The workshop will also help new researchers develop relationships with peers and experienced researchers and practitioners. Specific outcomes will include resources such as bibliographies, links to websites, video and slides sets from speakers and carefully crafted lists of courses, conferences, and journals. These resources will be helpful to researchers and educators who seek to expand their work in Technology-Mediated Social Participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summer Social Webshop 2012

The Summer Social Webshop was a 5-day workshop for doctoral students that was offered at the University of Maryland, College Park in August 2012, which was sponsored by the National Science Foundation. The aim of the Webshop was to introduce and train doctoral students in the methods needed to research, evaluate and develop social computing systems, particularly social media systems.

The workshop was attended by sixty students from across the USA, including six students identified and sponsored by the GRAND project, funded by the Canadian Research Council. The sixty doctoral students were selected from around 140 applicants. They came from a range of Universities that included both public and private institutions and from a range of disciplines, including: computer science, information science, psychology, sociology, journalism, American Studies, and business. Recruiting students from a range of disciplines was an important featuer of the workshop since social computing and social media research typically requires expertise, knowledge and methods from a combination of disciplines to achieve the best results.

The students arrived on campus on a Sunday night and left the following Friday after lunch. They ate all their meals together which was important for networking and encouraging deep discussions. Sessions started at 8.30 and went on into the evenng with informal discussion over lunch and dinner. 

Twenty established researchers from across the country were invited to present their work to the students and to lead formal and informal discussions with the students. These sessions covered fundamental methods and techniques such as social network analysis, questionnaire design, ethnography, etc. presented within an application context - eg, medicine, citizen science, communications etc. Members of faculty from the University of Maryland also presented their work and these included Jen Golbeck (Director, Human-Computer Interaction Laboratory), Ben Shneiderman (Founder, Human-Computer Interaction Laboratory) Lise Getoor (Professor, Computer Science), Brian Butler (Director, Master Information Management Program), Katie Shilton (Professor, iSchool) and Jennifer Preece (Professor and Dean, iSchool). Dr. Marc Smith ( Chair, Connected Action), Dr. Alan Neustadtl (Sociology Dept.), Dr. Ben Shneiderman (Computer Science Dept.) and Dr. Jennifer Preece (iSchool) co-organized the event and chaired the sessions and discussions that followed.

The students were fully engaged throughout the week in critiquing and discussing the presentations, tweeting to the outside world, preparing a summary report for publication, and working collaboratively on projects. On Thursday afternoon a field trip was organized to visit the New America Foundation in Washington DC to meet with speakers from the Foundation and others from FCC, Google, and the Bloomberg Foundation. 

Feedback from the doctoral student participants and the invited speakers indicated that the workshop achieved its goals of introducing and training the students in research methods relevant to social media research. Perhaps most important of all it was an excellent networking event that enabled the students to develop relationships with the speakers and with their peers that would have been difficult to achieve in any other way. Over a year later we are still receiving reports about the success of this workshop and how it has helped the students to develop their research careers.

A "Viewpoint" article related to this workshop was published in 2011 entitled "Realizing the Value of Social Media Requires Innovative Computing Research" was published in  Communications of the ACM, authored by Ben Shneiderman, Jennifer Preece, Peter Pirolli - See september 2011 | vol. 54 | no. 9 ...
